Text: By the rivers of Babylon we sat and wept when we remembered Zion.
Context: The psalmist begins with a vivid image of the Israelites in exile, expressing deep sorrow as they remember their homeland.

Text: On the poplars in our midst we hung our harps.
Context: The hanging of harps signifies the Israelites' lack of desire to sing or make music in a foreign land due to their sorrow.

Text: For there our captors demanded of us songs, and our tormentors asked for mirth: "Sing us one of the songs of Zion!”
Context: The captors' request for songs of Zion adds to the Israelites' sorrow by mocking their culture and traditions.

Text: How can we sing the songs of the LORD in a foreign land?
Context: This rhetorical question emphasizes the depth of the psalmist's despair and unwillingness to perform sacred songs in an alien and oppressive context.

Text: If I forget you, O Jerusalem, let my right hand forget its skill!
Context: The psalmist swears an oath of allegiance to Jerusalem, signaling a fierce commitment to their homeland.

Text: May my tongue cling to the roof of my mouth if I do not remember you, if I do not exalt Jerusalem above my chief joy.
Context: The psalmist emphasizes the deep emotional connection to Jerusalem and places it above all other joys.

Text: Remember, O LORD, against the sons of Edom, the day of Jerusalem’s fall, when they said, “Tear it down, tear it down, to its very foundation!”
Context: The psalmist recalls the role of the Edomites during the fall of Jerusalem with anger and seeks divine retribution.

Text: O Daughter Babylon, doomed to destruction, blessed shall he be who repays you as you have done to us.
Context: The psalmist speaks prophetically of Babylon’s future destruction and approves of retribution for the pain inflicted on the Israelites.

Text: Blessed shall he be who seizes your infants and dashes them against the rocks.
Context: The final verse of the psalm is a disturbing invocation of violence, reflecting the intensity of emotion felt by those in exile and desiring revenge.
